Kickstart.KICKSTART ASSESSMENT (condensed): 1. Financial literacy & analysis – uses ratios, percentages, and breakeven analysis for decisions.
Kickstart.Unnamed: 1: Could I explain our profit/loss in a way that even my younger cousin would understand?

Kickstart.KICKSTART ASSESSMENT (condensed): 2. Budgeting & forecasting – prepares budgets and business plans with financial strategies.
Kickstart.Unnamed: 1: If I had ₹1,000 more, I would know exactly how to spend it differently.

Kickstart.KICKSTART ASSESSMENT (condensed): 3. Accounting & compliance – applies double-entry, balance sheet analysis, and understands contracts.
Kickstart.Unnamed: 1: I track all income and expenses carefully without letting anything slip.

Kickstart.KICKSTART ASSESSMENT (condensed): 4. Negotiation & vendor management – conducts research, negotiates effectively, and optimizes cost/value.
Kickstart.Unnamed: 1: I pulled off discounts or deals that made our project smile (and our wallet happier)

Business Xray.Business X Ray ASSESSMENT (condensed): 1. Financial literacy & analysis – uses ratios, percentages, and breakeven analysis for decisions.
Business Xray.Assessment Questions: How confidently can I calculate and interpret key financial metrics like break-even, cost structure, and ROI for the business I studied?
Business Xray.Evidence Based Assessment: Students calculate BEP, ROI, profit margins using worksheets; analyse sample businesses; apply financial tools to their chosen business.

Business Xray.Business X Ray ASSESSMENT (condensed): 2. Budgeting & forecasting – prepares budgets and business plans with financial strategies.
Business Xray.Assessment Questions: How accurately was I able to estimate revenues, costs, and financial risks using field data and assumptions?
Business Xray.Evidence Based Assessment: Students estimate fixed/variable costs, sales volumes, waste, and stability; make assumptions for financial sheets; discuss financial risks.

Business Xray.Business X Ray ASSESSMENT (condensed): 3. Accounting & compliance – applies double-entry, balance sheet analysis, and understands contracts.
4. Negotiation & vendor management – conducts research, negotiates effectively, and optimizes cost/value.
Business Xray.Assessment Questions: How effectively did I communicate with owners/staff to gather accurate operational and financial information?
Business Xray.Evidence Based Assessment: Students interview owners, staff, suppliers; gather sensitive data (costs, supply chain, bottlenecks); negotiate access to information.

SDP.Commercial Readiness Parameter: 1. Financial Literacy & AnalysisUses ratios, percentages, breakeven logic
2. Budgeting & ForecastingPrepares budgets, forecasts, business plans

SDP.Evidence Used for Assessment (Observable: • Signed agreement with café/salon • Understanding of scope, roles, and commitments • Professional conduct in a paid engagement
SDP.Why / Why Not (Assessment Logic): While students do not engage with accounting systems or financial statements, they interact with a real commercial contract. Understanding obligations, scope, and delivery commitments allows assessment of basic compliance and professional responsibility, not accounting mechanics.
SDP.Commercial Readiness Parameter.1: “I understood the agreement we signed with the business and took responsibility for delivering what we committed to.”

SDP.Commercial Readiness Parameter: 4. Negotiation & Vendor ManagementResearch, negotiation, cost/value optimisation
SDP.Evidence Used for Assessment (Observable: • Partner scouting and outreach attempts • Pitching a paid collaboration • Handling objections and questions • Mentor and owner feedback
SDP.Why / Why Not (Assessment Logic): Students actively negotiate value, expectations, and trust with real business owners. Objection handling, follow-ups, and closing a paid engagement provide clear, observable evidence of negotiation and vendor interaction skills.
SDP.Commercial Readiness Parameter.1: “I confidently engaged with the business owner, handled questions or objections, and communicated the value of our work professionally.”

Accounts.Commercial Readiness Parameter: 1. Financial Literacy & AnalysisUses ratios, percentages, breakeven logic
Accounts.Evidence Used for Assessment (Observable: • Business health analysis during outclass visit• Interpretation of P&L (profit/loss reasoning)• Balance sheet analysis (assets, liabilities, stability, risk)• Founder session linking statements to decisions
Accounts.Why / Why Not (Assessment Logic): Students repeatedly interpret financial outputs to judge business health. While advanced ratios and breakeven may not be deeply calculated, students clearly demonstrate financial reasoning, interpretation, and decision logic, which fits the intent of this parameter.
Accounts.Commercial Readiness Parameter.1: “I can interpret financial statements and explain what they reveal about a business’s health and performance.”

Accounts.Commercial Readiness Parameter: 2. Budgeting & ForecastingPrepares budgets, forecasts, business plans
Accounts.Why / Why Not (Assessment Logic): The project focuses on historical transaction recording and analysis, not future planning. No activity requires students to create budgets, forecasts, or projections. Therefore, this parameter falls outside the project scope.

Accounts.Evidence Used for Assessment (Observable: • Single-entry recording of real transactions• Double-entry application using Golden Rules (Puru case study)• Trial balance preparation• P&L statement construction• Balance sheet preparation and analysis
Accounts.Why / Why Not (Assessment Logic): Accounting mechanics form the core spine of the project. Students move end-to-end through the accounting cycle, demonstrating technical accuracy, logical justification, and conceptual understanding. This parameter is fully observable and verifiable.
Accounts.Commercial Readiness Parameter.1: “I correctly applied accounting principles to record transactions and prepare financial statements.”

Accounts.Commercial Readiness Parameter: 4. Negotiation & Vendor ManagementResearch, negotiation, cost/value optimisation
Accounts.Why / Why Not (Assessment Logic): Although students visit real businesses to identify transactions, they do not negotiate prices, manage vendors, or optimise costs. The interaction is observational and analytical, not commercial negotiation-based.
